Morphine, as an opioid analgesic, directly reduces respiratory drive and palliates dyspnoea by decreasing the sensation of breathlessness, aligning with medical consensus for its use in palliative care. Benzodiazepines like Diazepam and Clobazam, while reducing anxiety, have minimal direct effect on respiratory function and are not primarily used for dyspnoea palliation. Haloperidol, an antipsychotic, is not used for dyspnoea and has no direct effect on respiratory symptoms.
